title: Osaka's Friendly Vibe
summary: Osaka locals are known for being more outgoing than other regions. Don't be surprised by friendly conversations or humor from strangers.

title: Osaka Kushikatsu Rules
summary: Never double-dip in the communal sauce! Dip your kushikatsu (fried skewer) once only. Use cabbage leaves to scoop extra sauce if needed.

title: Osaka Castle Park Crowds
summary: Osaka Castle is busiest 10 AM - 3 PM. Visit early morning or late afternoon. The surrounding park is lovely for picnics but gets crowded during hanami.

title: Shinsekai Area Awareness
summary: Shinsekai is safe but can feel rough around the edges. Great for kushikatsu and retro vibes. Stick to main streets at night.

title: Kanazawa Geisha Districts
summary: Kanazawa's Higashi Chaya is less crowded than Kyoto's Gion but same etiquette applies. Evening visits offer chance to hear shamisen music from teahouses.

title: Kenrokuen Garden Etiquette
summary: Stay on designated paths, don't touch the famous Kotoji lantern, and don't feed the koi. Early morning visits (7 AM) offer peaceful experience.

title: Kanazawa Fresh Seafood
summary: Omicho Market is best before noon for freshest seafood. Don't block narrow aisles. Some stalls let you eat purchases at small standing counters.

title: Gold Leaf Everything
summary: Kanazawa produces 99% of Japan's gold leaf. Gold leaf ice cream and souvenirs are local specialties - not a tourist trap but genuine tradition.

title: Sapporo Snow Festival
summary: Early February brings massive crowds. Book hotels months ahead. Dress in layers - it's freezing! Don't touch or climb on ice sculptures.

title: Hokkaido Driving in Winter
summary: Winter roads can be icy and treacherous. Rent cars with studded tires, drive slowly, and check road conditions. Chains may be required in mountains.

title: Hokkaido Farm Visits
summary: Many Hokkaido farms welcome visitors but call ahead. Don't enter fields without permission. Buy directly from farms for freshest dairy and produce.

title: Otaru Canal District
summary: The historic canal is beautiful but narrow paths get crowded. Visit at dusk when gas lamps light up. Winter illumination is magical but extremely cold.

title: Hakodate Morning Market
summary: Arrive by 6-7 AM for best selection. The 'squid fishing' experience is fun but pricey. Seafood donburi here is fresher than anywhere.

title: Nagoya Hitsumabushi Style
summary: Eat hitsumabushi (grilled eel on rice) in three ways: plain, with condiments, then as ochazuke (with tea). This is the traditional Nagoya method.

title: Nagoya Castle Reconstruction
summary: The main tower is being rebuilt using traditional methods - check if it's open. Honmaru Palace is the highlight and fully restored with stunning artwork.

title: Takayama Old Town
summary: The Sanmachi historic district is car-free but narrow. Visit sake breweries (look for sugidama balls) and try Hida beef. Morning markets run 7 AM - noon.

title: Shirakawa-go Etiquette
summary: These are real homes - don't enter private property or peer into windows. Stay on designated paths. Winter illumination requires lottery reservation.

title: Fukuoka Yatai Culture
summary: Yatai (food stalls) are a Fukuoka tradition. Squeeze in, order quickly, eat, and make room for others. Cash only. Best experience is late night.

title: Beppu Onsen Hopping
summary: Beppu has 8 major hot spring areas. The 'Hells' are for viewing only - don't try to bathe in them! Public baths are very affordable (¬•100-300).

title: Nagasaki Peace Park
summary: Like Hiroshima, maintain solemn respect at the Peace Park and Atomic Bomb Museum. The Peace Statue is for reflection, not casual selfies.

title: Okinawa Beach Etiquette
summary: Don't take coral or shells from beaches - it's illegal. Use reef-safe sunscreen. Jellyfish are common in summer - look for warning signs.

title: Okinawa Cultural Sensitivity
summary: Okinawa has distinct culture from mainland Japan. Learn about Ryukyu Kingdom history. US military bases are sensitive topics - be respectful in discussions.

title: Shuri Castle Reconstruction
summary: Shuri Castle is being rebuilt after the 2019 fire. Construction viewing is available. The surrounding Shurijo Park and stone walls remain impressive.

title: Tea Ceremony Participation
summary: Accept the tea bowl with your right hand, place in left palm, rotate clockwise 2-3 times to avoid drinking from the front. Finish in 3 sips.

title: Tea Ceremony Seating
summary: Kneel in seiza position if possible, or sit cross-legged if offered. Don't step on the edges of tatami mats. Remove watches and jewelry beforehand.

title: Tea Ceremony Sweets
summary: Eat the wagashi (sweet) completely before drinking tea. Use the provided pick or paper. The sweet balances the bitter matcha.

title: Karaoke Room Etiquette
summary: Everyone takes turns - don't hog the mic. Clap and cheer for others even if they're terrible. Order food/drinks to support the establishment.

title: Karaoke Time Limits
summary: Karaoke is charged by time (usually 30-min blocks). Staff will call when time is up - extend or leave promptly. Peak hours have strict limits.

title: Baseball Game Atmosphere
summary: Japanese baseball fans are organized - each team has coordinated cheers and songs. Join in! Trumpets and drums are common. It's louder than you'd expect.

title: Stadium Food and Drink
summary: Beer vendors walk through stands - raise your hand to order. Bring your own food or buy bento at the stadium. Clean up all trash when leaving.

title: Sumo Tournament Etiquette
summary: Arrive early for good seats. Don't throw cushions (zabuton) unless a yokozuna is upset - it's tradition but can result in ejection. Stay quiet during bouts.

title: Sumo Morning Practice
summary: Some sumo stables allow visitors to watch morning practice (keiko). Contact in advance, arrive early (6-7 AM), sit quietly, and don't take flash photos.

title: Arcade Etiquette
summary: Don't bang on machines or get aggressive. Wait your turn for popular games. Prize machines (UFO catchers) are skill-based - staff may help if you're close.

title: Pachinko Parlor Basics
summary: Pachinko is gambling-adjacent and can be overwhelming. It's extremely loud. Winnings are exchanged for prizes, then traded for cash at nearby shops.

title: Kimono Rental Etiquette
summary: Walk with smaller steps in kimono. Sit carefully to avoid wrinkling. Use restroom before dressing - it's complicated! Return on time to avoid fees.

title: Cooking Class Participation
summary: Listen to instructions fully before starting. Ask questions if unsure. Most classes are hands-on - don't just watch. Dietary restrictions should be mentioned at booking.

title: Cherry Blossom Forecast
summary: Peak bloom varies by region - Tokyo late March, Kyoto early April, Hokkaido early May. Check forecasts and be flexible. Peak lasts only 1-2 weeks.

title: Hanami Blue Tarp Culture
summary: Groups reserve spots with blue tarps early morning. It's OK to sit on edges of unclaimed tarps. Don't move others' belongings or reserved spaces.

title: Yozakura Night Viewing
summary: Many parks illuminate cherry blossoms at night (yozakura). Bring warm clothes - spring nights are cold. Food stalls often set up for evening crowds.

title: Rainy Season Preparation
summary: Tsuyu (rainy season) runs mid-June to mid-July. Pack waterproof bags, quick-dry clothes, and a good umbrella. Indoor backup plans are essential.

title: Hydrangea Season
summary: Ajisai (hydrangeas) bloom during rainy season (June). Temples like Meigetsu-in in Kamakura are famous spots. Actually beautiful in the rain!

title: Summer Heat Precautions
summary: Japanese summers are hot and humid (35¬∞C+). Carry a hand towel, stay hydrated, and use cooling products from convenience stores. Heat stroke is real.

title: Fireworks Festival Etiquette
summary: Arrive hours early for spots at popular hanabi (fireworks). Sit on provided tarps, don't stand blocking others. Many wear yukata. Clean up everything after.

title: Obon Travel Warning
summary: Obon (mid-August) is peak domestic travel. Trains, flights, and hotels book up fast. Expect huge crowds at popular destinations. Book months ahead.

title: Bon Odori Participation
summary: Anyone can join bon odori (summer festival dances). Follow the simple steps - locals will help. Wearing yukata adds to the experience but isn't required.

title: Momiji Hunting Best Spots
summary: Koyo (autumn colors) peaks mid-November in Kyoto, early November in Tokyo, late October in mountains. Nikko and Kyoto are famously spectacular.

title: Night Illuminations
summary: Autumn and winter bring spectacular light-up events at temples and gardens. Check schedules - many require advance tickets. Photography is often allowed.

title: Seven-Five-Three Festival
summary: Shichi-Go-San (Nov 15) celebrates children aged 3, 5, and 7. Shrines will be busy with families in traditional dress. A lovely cultural sight!

title: Winter Illuminations
summary: Cities light up from November-February with spectacular displays. Tokyo, Osaka, Kobe have famous spots. Dress warmly - you'll be outside a lot.

title: Christmas in Japan
summary: Christmas isn't a holiday but is celebrated commercially. KFC for dinner is tradition! Couples treat it like Valentine's Day. Stores close normal hours.

title: New Year Closures
summary: Many businesses close Dec 31 - Jan 3. Restaurants, shops, and attractions have reduced hours. Plan accordingly and check specific venue schedules.

title: Osechi New Year Food
summary: Traditional osechi boxes are available at department stores (order in advance). Each food has symbolic meaning for the new year. Try at least once!

title: Setsubun Bean Throwing
summary: On Feb 3, temples hold setsubun events - beans are thrown to drive out evil. Catch them for good luck! Ehomaki (long sushi roll) is eaten facing lucky direction.

title: Plum Blossom Season
summary: Ume (plum blossoms) bloom Feb-March, before cherry blossoms. Less crowded but equally beautiful. Kairakuen in Mito and Kitano Tenmangu in Kyoto are famous.

title: Ski Resort Etiquette
summary: Follow slope rules strictly. Yield to downhill skiers. No stopping in blind spots. Apr√®s-ski onsen is tradition - follow all onsen rules.

title: Golden Week Chaos
summary: Golden Week (late April - early May) is Japan's longest holiday. Everything is crowded and expensive. Book 3+ months ahead or avoid entirely.

title: Typhoon Season Awareness
summary: Typhoons hit Japan Aug-Oct, mainly affecting western/southern regions. Monitor forecasts, have flexible plans, and know your hotel's emergency procedures.

title: Nikko Temple Complex
summary: Nikko's shrines and temples are UNESCO sites. The famous 'see no evil' monkeys are at Toshogu. Buy the combination ticket. Allow a full day.

title: Kamakura Day Trip Tips
summary: Start early to avoid crowds. The hiking trails between temples are a hidden gem. Great Buddha is iconic but temples like Hokokuji (bamboo) are special.

title: Mt. Fuji Climbing Season
summary: Official climbing season is July-early September only. Book mountain huts months ahead. Start at night to reach summit for sunrise. It's harder than it looks!

title: Mt. Fuji Viewing Etiquette
summary: Fuji views depend on weather - often cloudy by afternoon. Best viewing is early morning. Respect private property when seeking view spots.

title: Hakone Busy Periods
summary: Hakone is packed on weekends and holidays. Weekday visits are far more pleasant. The 'Hakone Free Pass' is worth it for multi-transport exploration.

title: Naoshima Art Island
summary: This art island has limited accommodation - book far ahead or day-trip from Takamatsu. Bicycles are the best way around. Museums close on different days.

title: Matsuyama Dogo Onsen
summary: Dogo Onsen is one of Japan's oldest bathhouses. Main building is under renovation but still operating. Go early morning or evening to avoid tour groups.

title: Iya Valley Remoteness
summary: Iya Valley is remote - rent a car or join a tour. Limited bus service exists but is infrequent. The vine bridges and scenery are worth the effort.

title: Koyasan Temple Stay
summary: Staying at a temple (shukubo) on Koyasan is unforgettable. Wake early for morning prayers. Vegetarian shojin ryori meals are included. Book directly with temples.

title: Koyasan Okunoin Cemetery
summary: Walk respectfully through Japan's largest cemetery. Don't step on graves, speak quietly, and don't disturb offerings. Most atmospheric at dusk or dawn.

title: Kumano Kodo Preparation
summary: This ancient pilgrimage route requires proper hiking gear and fitness. Book lodging along the route in advance. Luggage forwarding services are available.

title: Maid Cafe Protocol
summary: Maid cafes have specific rules - no touching staff, ask permission for photos, follow the 'moe' rituals. Expect a table charge and themed food/drinks.

title: Akihabara Shopping Tips
summary: Compare prices between stores - they vary significantly. Tax-free available at most electronics shops. Beware of 'duty-free' items that can't be used in Japan.

title: Robot Restaurant Experience
summary: It's loud, flashy, and touristy but uniquely Japanese. Book online for discounts. Don't expect fine dining - it's about the show. Cameras are allowed.

title: TeamLab Booking Essential
summary: TeamLab exhibits require advance tickets - often sold out weeks ahead. Wear comfortable shoes (lots of walking) and clothes you don't mind getting wet.

title: Ghibli Museum Tickets
summary: Ghibli Museum tickets sell out months in advance and must be bought from Lawson convenience stores (online for foreigners). No same-day tickets available.

title: DisneySea vs Disneyland
summary: DisneySea is unique to Japan and generally preferred by adults. Both parks are extremely crowded - weekdays are better. Buy tickets in advance online.

title: Universal Studios Japan Tips
summary: Buy Express Pass for popular rides - regular lines can be 2+ hours. Harry Potter area often has entry limits. Go on weekdays if possible.
